Comment: It's not that surprising really.   A lot of people are desperate for change.   They voted for Trump because he pretended that he was going to shake up the system. Of course, he's not fighting the real system that's oppressing people, which is unbridled financial capitalism, he's attacking the rule of law instead. But many people confuse using "forbidden" slurs on TV, and saying things you're not supposed to say,  with breaking the system. Of course Trump is a pure product of the establishment. He never worked an honest day in his life. But most voters' analysis doesn't go that far. They want to say fuck you, and he's an excellent candidate for that.   Now, not everyone is that stupid. At some point, some people understand who Trump is. And they realize that the *real* people who want to change things are the progressives. I'm certain that progressives could be successful in poor red state districts if people there weren't completely brainwashed by decades of Fox News.

Comment: >  Fact is, he won or was second in many early primaries. Biden was well down. Then Biden wins South Carolina and for some reason that was enough. Hell, Sanders won some of the primaries after. Had they gotten behind him this mess would not have happened.  After SC, Biden was only 8 pledged delegates behind Bernie and led in total vote count.  He wasn't way down.  The problem for Bernie was SC showed that Pete and Amy's early success hadn't earned them added support in later states and most importantly among black voters (Biden won 61% of them with Bernie being second with 14%, meaning they got less than 14% of the black vote).  Simply, it was clear that Pete and Amy had no room to grow thus they couldn't win.  So they dropped out and endorsed the candidate closer to them politically.  Ironically, it might have better for Bernie if he allowed Pete to claim his Iowa win without controversy and narrowly win in New Hampshire as that could have potentially made him do at least slightly better in SC.

Comment: > What motivates Americans is money. Promise them you'll lower their taxes or lower the price of eggs and they will vote for you.   Well there‚Äôs a cost to living and most people are reasonably concerned about it becoming too high for themselves and their families in the current system. The point is that we should be able to tell voters how the rule of law helps their lives. We should be able to say we will crack down on corporations that violate the law too to make the economy fairer, and close down tax loopholes for the wealthy. Same goes for all the other abstract principles we like.   If we don‚Äôt ban things like Congressional stock trading when we have the chance (like Pelosi quietly killing that bill when they had a majority) or give corporations real consequences for breaking the law (only 1 person went to jail after 08 and PG&E gets nothing but fines from completely blue areas), then we can‚Äôt really use ‚Äúthe rule of law‚Äù as an argument anyone will believe. It won‚Äôt matter that Trump is worse, we won‚Äôt be seen as actually caring or an honest alternative.  Trump will eventually suffer the consequences of this very stupid trade war, but we really need to rely on something other than Republicans screwing up if we want to win elections
